items.title: I can define fossil fuels, biofuels, renewable and non-renewable resources
items.what: Fossil fuels are hydrocarbons formed from decomposed organisms over millions of years and are non-renewable. Biofuels are produced from biological matter (biomass) and are renewable because they can be replenished at the rate they are consumed.
items.why: These definitions form the foundation for understanding energy sustainability and the environmental impacts of different fuel choices in society.
items.example: Coal is a fossil fuel (non-renewable) formed over millions of years, while bioethanol is a biofuel (renewable) produced from wheat fermentation within months.

subtopic.name: Types of Fuels
subtopic.what: This subtopic explores the distinction between fossil fuels and biofuels, their sources, production methods, and renewability. It covers coal, natural gas, petroleum, biogas, bioethanol, and biodiesel, including their formation processes and societal impacts.
subtopic.why: Understanding different fuel types and their renewability is critical for evaluating energy sustainability and environmental impact. This knowledge helps in making informed decisions about energy use, policy, and the transition from non-renewable to renewable energy sources.

items.title: I can compare the three main types of fossil fuels: coal, natural gas, and petroleum
items.what: Coal is sedimentary rock formed from plant remains under high pressure. Natural gas is primarily methane released through fracking. Petroleum (crude oil) is a liquid hydrocarbon mixture separated by fractional distillation.
items.why: Each fossil fuel has different extraction methods, energy content, and environmental impacts, making comparison essential for energy planning and policy.
items.example: Black coal in NSW is buried deeper and has higher carbon content than brown coal in Victoria, making it more economically valuable despite harder extraction.

items.title: I can compare the three main types of biofuels: biogas, bioethanol, and biodiesel
items.what: Biogas is methane-rich gas from anaerobic bacterial decomposition of organic waste. Bioethanol is ethanol produced from glucose fermentation. Biodiesel is a mixture of methyl esters from transesterification of vegetable oils or animal fats with methanol.
items.why: Understanding these biofuel types helps evaluate renewable energy options and their production requirements, costs, and environmental benefits compared to fossil fuels.
items.example: Biogas from digesters contains 50-75% methane, bioethanol from wheat creates E10 petrol blend (10% ethanol), and biodiesel from vegetable oils creates B5 diesel blend (5% biodiesel).

items.title: I can describe the process of producing bioethanol from glucose
items.what: Enzymes break down cellulose and starch to sucrose, then yeast invertase converts sucrose to glucose. Yeast zymase then catalyzes glucose fermentation into ethanol and carbon dioxide anaerobically.
items.why: This process transforms renewable plant materials into usable liquid fuel, reducing dependence on crude oil and lowering greenhouse gas emissions.
items.example: In wheat-based bioethanol production, enzymes convert starch to glucose, then yeast fermentation produces aqueous ethanol which must be purified by distillation.

items.title: I can recall that distillation is used to purify bioethanol after fermentation
items.what: Fermentation produces aqueous ethanol mixed with water. Distillation separates the ethanol from water by exploiting their different boiling points, producing more concentrated ethanol for fuel use.
items.why: Pure or highly concentrated ethanol is necessary for effective fuel blending with petrol, as water content reduces combustion efficiency and engine performance.
items.example: After fermentation produces C2H5OH(aq), distillation increases ethanol concentration from approximately 10-15% to over 95% for use in E10 fuel blends.

items.title: I can write the balanced equation for glucose fermentation
items.what: The fermentation equation is C6H12O6(aq) → 2C2H5OH(aq) + 2CO2(g), showing one glucose molecule producing two ethanol molecules and two carbon dioxide molecules.
items.why: This equation is fundamental to understanding bioethanol production efficiency, yield calculations, and the stoichiometry of biofuel manufacturing processes.
items.example: From 180 g of glucose (1 mol), fermentation produces 92 g of ethanol (2 mol) and 88 g of carbon dioxide (2 mol) under anaerobic conditions.

items.title: I can explain the advantages and disadvantages of fossil fuels and biofuels
items.what: Fossil fuels are energy-dense, easily transported, and have established infrastructure but are non-renewable and produce greenhouse gases. Biofuels are renewable and can reduce emissions but require land, water, and compete with food production.
items.why: Weighing these trade-offs is essential for energy policy, understanding the food versus fuel debate, and planning sustainable energy transitions.
items.example: Coal is cheap and abundant but produces SO2 contributing to acid rain. Bioethanol reduces greenhouse gas emissions but growing wheat for fuel requires large volumes of water.

items.title: I can describe the process of photosynthesis and its products
items.what: Photosynthesis is an anabolic, endothermic process where chlorophyll in plant chloroplasts uses light energy to convert carbon dioxide and water into glucose and oxygen through a series of enzyme-controlled steps.
items.why: Photosynthesis is the primary source of glucose for cellular respiration and the origin of oxygen in Earth's atmosphere, making it essential for life and biofuel production.
items.example: In green leaves, chloroplasts absorb sunlight and use it to transform 6 molecules of CO2 and 6 molecules of H2O into 1 molecule of glucose and 6 molecules of oxygen.

subtopic.name: Chemical Energy in Nature
subtopic.what: This subtopic examines how plants and animals produce and transform energy through photosynthesis and cellular respiration. It covers the chemical equations, conditions, and relationship between these complementary biological processes.
subtopic.why: These processes form the foundation of energy flow in ecosystems and are the basis for all biofuels. Understanding them connects light energy to usable chemical energy and explains how organisms meet their energy needs.

items.title: I can write and interpret the balanced equation for photosynthesis
items.what: The photosynthesis equation is 6CO2(g) + 6H2O(l) → C6H12O6(aq) + 6O2(g), requiring light energy and chlorophyll. It shows the mole ratio of 6:6:1:6 for reactants and products.
items.why: This equation allows calculation of reactant requirements and product yields, and demonstrates the stoichiometric relationships in biological energy transformation.
items.example: To produce 180 g of glucose (1 mol), plants require 264 g of carbon dioxide (6 mol) and 108 g of water (6 mol), releasing 192 g of oxygen (6 mol).

subtopic.name: Chemical Energy in Nature
subtopic.what: This subtopic examines how plants and animals produce and transform energy through photosynthesis and cellular respiration. It covers the chemical equations, conditions, and relationship between these complementary biological processes.
subtopic.why: These processes form the foundation of energy flow in ecosystems and are the basis for all biofuels. Understanding them connects light energy to usable chemical energy and explains how organisms meet their energy needs.

items.title: I can describe cellular respiration and distinguish aerobic from anaerobic types
items.what: Cellular respiration is a catabolic process breaking down glucose to release energy as ATP. Aerobic respiration occurs in mitochondria with oxygen, producing carbon dioxide and water. Anaerobic respiration (fermentation) occurs without oxygen, producing ethanol or lactic acid.
items.why: Cellular respiration provides usable energy for all life processes. Understanding both types explains energy production in different conditions and links to bioethanol production.
items.example: In muscle cells during exercise, aerobic respiration produces ATP efficiently with oxygen. During intense exercise, anaerobic respiration produces lactic acid causing muscle cramping.

subtopic.why: These processes form the foundation of energy flow in ecosystems and are the basis for all biofuels. Understanding them connects light energy to usable chemical energy and explains how organisms meet their energy needs.

items.title: I can write the balanced equation for aerobic cellular respiration
items.what: The aerobic cellular respiration equation is C6H12O6(aq) + 6O2(g) → 6CO2(g) + 6H2O(l). This shows glucose is oxidized (carbon changes from 0 to +4 oxidation state) and oxygen is reduced.
items.why: This equation demonstrates how organisms extract energy from glucose and shows the complementary relationship between respiration and photosynthesis, forming a continuous cycle.
items.example: One mole of glucose (180 g) reacts with 6 moles of oxygen (192 g) in mitochondria to produce 6 moles of carbon dioxide (264 g) and 6 moles of water (108 g), releasing energy as ATP.

subtopic.why: These processes form the foundation of energy flow in ecosystems and are the basis for all biofuels. Understanding them connects light energy to usable chemical energy and explains how organisms meet their energy needs.

items.title: I can explain the relationship between photosynthesis and cellular respiration
items.what: The products of photosynthesis (glucose and oxygen) are the reactants for cellular respiration, while the products of cellular respiration (carbon dioxide and water) are reactants for photosynthesis, creating a complementary cycle.
items.why: This relationship shows how carbon, hydrogen, and oxygen cycle through organisms and environments, forming the basis of energy flow in ecosystems and the carbon cycle.
items.example: Plants produce glucose and oxygen in chloroplasts through photosynthesis. Both plants and animals use this glucose and oxygen in mitochondria for cellular respiration, releasing carbon dioxide and water back for photosynthesis.

subtopic.why: These processes form the foundation of energy flow in ecosystems and are the basis for all biofuels. Understanding them connects light energy to usable chemical energy and explains how organisms meet their energy needs.

items.title: I can compare and contrast exothermic and endothermic reactions
items.what: Exothermic reactions release heat to the environment, have negative ΔH values, and products at lower energy than reactants. Endothermic reactions absorb heat from the environment, have positive ΔH values, and products at higher energy than reactants.
items.why: This distinction determines whether reactions require or produce energy, which is critical for fuel selection, energy calculations, and understanding reaction spontaneity and stability.
items.example: Combustion of methane is exothermic (ΔH = -890 kJ mol⁻¹), releasing heat for cooking. Photosynthesis is endothermic (positive ΔH), requiring sunlight input to produce glucose.

subtopic.name: Energy Changes in Reactions
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers the energy transformations occurring during chemical reactions, distinguishing between exothermic and endothermic processes. It includes understanding activation energy, enthalpy changes, and how to represent these using energy profile diagrams.
subtopic.why: Understanding energy changes is fundamental to predicting reaction behavior, calculating energy yields from fuels, and representing chemical processes accurately. This knowledge is essential for fuel efficiency analysis and thermochemistry.

items.title: I can define activation energy and explain its role in reactions
items.what: Activation energy (Ea) is the minimum energy required for reactant bonds to break so a chemical reaction can proceed. It represents the energy barrier that must be overcome regardless of whether the reaction is exothermic or endothermic.
items.why: Activation energy determines reaction rate and explains why some reactions need heating or catalysts to begin, even if they ultimately release energy.
items.example: Methane combustion has an activation energy barrier requiring an ignition source (spark or flame) to start the reaction, even though the overall reaction releases 890 kJ mol⁻¹.

subtopic.name: Energy Changes in Reactions
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers the energy transformations occurring during chemical reactions, distinguishing between exothermic and endothermic processes. It includes understanding activation energy, enthalpy changes, and how to represent these using energy profile diagrams.
subtopic.why: Understanding energy changes is fundamental to predicting reaction behavior, calculating energy yields from fuels, and representing chemical processes accurately. This knowledge is essential for fuel efficiency analysis and thermochemistry.

items.title: I can define enthalpy and enthalpy change with appropriate units
items.what: Enthalpy (H) is the internal chemical energy of a substance. Enthalpy change (ΔH) is the difference between products and reactants energy, measured in kJ, kJ mol⁻¹ (per mole of substance), or kJ g⁻¹ (per gram of mixture).
items.why: These concepts and units allow quantitative comparison of energy content in different fuels and calculation of energy released in chemical reactions.
items.example: Methane combustion has ΔH = -890 kJ mol⁻¹ (per mole of methane) or -55.6 kJ g⁻¹ (per gram of methane), showing energy released when burning this fuel.

subtopic.what: This subtopic covers the energy transformations occurring during chemical reactions, distinguishing between exothermic and endothermic processes. It includes understanding activation energy, enthalpy changes, and how to represent these using energy profile diagrams.
subtopic.why: Understanding energy changes is fundamental to predicting reaction behavior, calculating energy yields from fuels, and representing chemical processes accurately. This knowledge is essential for fuel efficiency analysis and thermochemistry.

items.title: I can draw and fully label energy profile diagrams for exothermic and endothermic reactions
items.what: Energy profile diagrams plot energy against reaction progress, showing reactant and product energy levels, activation energy (Ea) as an arrow from reactants to peak, and enthalpy change (ΔH) as an arrow between reactant and product levels.
items.why: These diagrams provide visual representations of energy transformations, making it easier to understand and communicate reaction energetics and compare different reactions.
items.example: For methane combustion, reactants start at a higher energy level, the curve rises to show activation energy, then drops below reactants showing products at lower energy with ΔH = -890 kJ mol⁻¹ arrow pointing downward.

subtopic.what: This subtopic covers the energy transformations occurring during chemical reactions, distinguishing between exothermic and endothermic processes. It includes understanding activation energy, enthalpy changes, and how to represent these using energy profile diagrams.
subtopic.why: Understanding energy changes is fundamental to predicting reaction behavior, calculating energy yields from fuels, and representing chemical processes accurately. This knowledge is essential for fuel efficiency analysis and thermochemistry.

items.title: I can explain bond breaking and bond forming in terms of energy
items.what: Breaking bonds requires energy input from the environment (endothermic process). Forming bonds releases energy to the environment (exothermic process). The overall enthalpy change equals energy for breaking bonds minus energy from forming bonds.
items.why: This understanding explains why reactions are exothermic or endothermic based on the relative strengths and numbers of bonds broken and formed.
items.example: In methane combustion, breaking C-H and O=O bonds requires energy, but forming C=O and H-O bonds releases more energy, making the overall reaction exothermic with net energy release.

subtopic.why: Understanding energy changes is fundamental to predicting reaction behavior, calculating energy yields from fuels, and representing chemical processes accurately. This knowledge is essential for fuel efficiency analysis and thermochemistry.

items.title: I can identify the limiting reagent in a combustion reaction
items.what: The limiting reagent is the reactant that is completely consumed first, determining the maximum amount of product formed. It is identified by comparing the mole ratio of reactants present to the mole ratio required by the balanced equation.
items.why: Identifying the limiting reagent is essential for calculating actual product yields, determining if combustion is complete or incomplete, and understanding fuel efficiency.
items.example: If 2.0 mol of methane reacts with 6.0 mol of oxygen, the equation requires 2 mol O2 per 1 mol CH4, so 2.0 mol CH4 needs 4.0 mol O2. Since 6.0 mol O2 is present, methane is limiting and oxygen is in excess.

subtopic.name: Combustion Reactions
subtopic.what: This subtopic examines complete and incomplete combustion reactions of organic fuels, including writing balanced thermochemical equations and determining limiting reagents. It covers stoichiometric calculations for combustion products and energy released.
subtopic.why: Combustion reactions are the primary method of extracting energy from fuels for electricity, heating, and transportation. Understanding these reactions enables fuel efficiency calculations, emissions predictions, and safety analysis for incomplete combustion scenarios.

items.title: I can calculate mass, concentration, or volume of reactants or products with a limiting reagent present
items.what: Calculate moles of each reactant, use mole ratios to identify the limiting reagent, then use the limiting reagent's moles with stoichiometric ratios to find moles of desired product, converting to mass, concentration, or volume as needed.
items.why: These calculations predict actual amounts of products formed and reactants consumed in real-world combustion scenarios where reagents are not in perfect stoichiometric ratios.
items.example: With 8.0 g methane (0.50 mol) and 16.0 g oxygen (0.50 mol), the ratio shows oxygen is limiting for incomplete combustion: 2CH4 + 3O2 → 2CO + 4H2O produces 0.33 mol CO = 9.3 g.

subtopic.name: Combustion Reactions
subtopic.what: This subtopic examines complete and incomplete combustion reactions of organic fuels, including writing balanced thermochemical equations and determining limiting reagents. It covers stoichiometric calculations for combustion products and energy released.
subtopic.why: Combustion reactions are the primary method of extracting energy from fuels for electricity, heating, and transportation. Understanding these reactions enables fuel efficiency calculations, emissions predictions, and safety analysis for incomplete combustion scenarios.

items.title: I can compare complete and incomplete combustion reactions
items.what: Complete combustion occurs with excess oxygen, producing only carbon dioxide and water, with the fuel as the limiting reagent. Incomplete combustion occurs with insufficient oxygen (oxygen limiting), producing carbon monoxide, solid carbon, and water, releasing less energy.
items.why: This distinction affects fuel efficiency, safety (carbon monoxide is toxic), emissions, and energy output. Understanding both types is critical for designing combustion systems.
items.example: Complete combustion: CH4 + 2O2 → CO2 + 2H2O releases 890 kJ mol⁻¹. Incomplete combustion: 2CH4 + 3O2 → 2CO + 4H2O releases less energy and produces poisonous carbon monoxide.

subtopic.name: Combustion Reactions
subtopic.what: This subtopic examines complete and incomplete combustion reactions of organic fuels, including writing balanced thermochemical equations and determining limiting reagents. It covers stoichiometric calculations for combustion products and energy released.
subtopic.why: Combustion reactions are the primary method of extracting energy from fuels for electricity, heating, and transportation. Understanding these reactions enables fuel efficiency calculations, emissions predictions, and safety analysis for incomplete combustion scenarios.

items.title: I can state that all combustion reactions are exothermic
items.what: All combustion reactions of organic fuels with oxygen release heat energy to the surroundings, making them exothermic with negative enthalpy change values. This released heat is the useful energy extracted from fuels.
items.why: This fundamental property explains why combustion is used for energy generation in power plants, vehicles, and heating systems worldwide.
items.example: Octane combustion in petrol engines is exothermic: 2C8H18 + 25O2 → 16CO2 + 18H2O with ΔH = -10,160 kJ mol⁻¹, releasing heat that powers the vehicle.

subtopic.why: Combustion reactions are the primary method of extracting energy from fuels for electricity, heating, and transportation. Understanding these reactions enables fuel efficiency calculations, emissions predictions, and safety analysis for incomplete combustion scenarios.

items.title: I can write balanced thermochemical equations for complete combustion
items.what: Balanced thermochemical equations for complete combustion show organic fuel reacting with oxygen to produce carbon dioxide and water (liquid at SLC), include state symbols, and show negative enthalpy change values from data tables.
items.why: These equations enable calculation of energy released, products formed, and reactants required for complete combustion reactions in practical applications.
items.example: Complete combustion of methane at standard conditions: CH4(g) + 2O2(g) → CO2(g) + 2H2O(l) ΔH = -890 kJ mol⁻¹, showing all species states and energy released.

subtopic.name: Combustion Reactions

subtopic.why: Combustion reactions are the primary method of extracting energy from fuels for electricity, heating, and transportation. Understanding these reactions enables fuel efficiency calculations, emissions predictions, and safety analysis for incomplete combustion scenarios.

items.title: I can write balanced equations for incomplete combustion using experimental data
items.what: Incomplete combustion equations show organic fuel reacting with limited oxygen to produce carbon monoxide or solid carbon along with water. The products formed depend on oxygen availability and are determined from experimental observations or data.
items.why: These equations model real-world scenarios where insufficient oxygen causes incomplete combustion, producing toxic gases and reducing energy efficiency.
items.example: Incomplete combustion of propane with insufficient ventilation: 2C3H8(g) + 7O2(g) → 6CO(g) + 8H2O(l), producing toxic carbon monoxide instead of carbon dioxide.

subtopic.what: This subtopic examines complete and incomplete combustion reactions of organic fuels, including writing balanced thermochemical equations and determining limiting reagents. It covers stoichiometric calculations for combustion products and energy released.
subtopic.why: Combustion reactions are the primary method of extracting energy from fuels for electricity, heating, and transportation. Understanding these reactions enables fuel efficiency calculations, emissions predictions, and safety analysis for incomplete combustion scenarios.

items.title: I can calculate energy released from fuel combustion using limiting reagent concepts
items.what: Determine the limiting reagent, calculate moles consumed based on this reagent, then multiply by the molar enthalpy of combustion to find total energy released, converting to appropriate units (kJ, MJ) as needed.
items.why: These calculations predict actual energy output from combustion reactions in engines, power plants, and heating systems where fuel and oxygen may not be in ideal ratios.
items.example: If 0.50 mol oxygen is limiting in incomplete methane combustion (2CH4 + 3O2 → 2CO + 4H2O), and combustion releases 519 kJ mol⁻¹ of CH4, then 0.33 mol CH4 consumed releases 171 kJ total energy.
